turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: I'm pulling my hair out here! We've had claim #47829 denied three times now for 'lack of medical necessity'. The doctor clearly documented why the procedure was necessary. What gives?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: I understand your frustration. Let me look into claim #47829. Could you please provide the patient's name and date of service so I can pull up the relevant information?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Sure, it's John Smith, date of service was 2024-03-15. And honestly, this feels like a wild goose chase. Is there *anything* specific I can look for in the denial reason to figure out what they're missing? It just says 'lack of medical necessity' – super helpful, right?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Okay, I've reviewed the denial for claim #47829. While the documentation does state the physician's reasoning, the payer's guidelines require specific ICD-10 codes to be linked to the CPT code for the procedure. I see that the primary diagnosis code listed doesn't directly support the procedure according to their policy. Have you checked if perhaps there is a more specific, payable diagnosis code that could be used? I can also provide a link to the payer's medical policy if that would be helpful.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Aha! Okay, that makes sense. We'll double-check the ICD-10 codes against the payer's policy. Thanks for pointing that out – I appreciate you digging into the details. A link to their policy would be great just to be absolutely sure. Hopefully, this will solve the issue this time.
